G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 19A, 19C..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $7,000, inclusive of medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering, but is within the jurisdictional limits of the Worcester District Court. See G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 19A, 19C.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2..proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court because the events giving rise to this claim occurred in Worcester, Worcester County, Massachusetts. See G.L. c. 223, § 2.

Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass\.raw_text: Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass’n, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 333, 340–41 (2010).
Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass\.proposition: The icy condition on the path was not open and obvious to Plaintiff, or, to the extent it was visible at all, it appeared to be a normal, passable walkway that other persons used, and Plaintiff acted reasonably in walking there. See Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass’n, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 333, 340–41 (2010).
Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass\.case_name: Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condominium Association
Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass\.support_reasoning: The case does not address whether the particular icy condition was open and obvious to the plaintiff or whether it appeared to be a normal, passable walkway; in fact, the plaintiff expressly testified that she recognized the danger and knew she had to be especially careful. Soederberg instead holds that, even where an ice hazard is open and obvious and the plaintiff has alternatives, the open and obvious doctrine does not negate the landowner’s duty to remedy unnatural accumulations in known paths of travel and that such issues go to comparative negligence. Thus, the opinion supports a different legal principle than the one stated in the proposition.
Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass\.relevant_excerpt: “According to her own testimony, she recognized the danger and knew that she ‘had to be especially careful.’ Seeing that ‘it was just a few more steps’ before she ‘got out of the danger zone,’ she concluded that she could navigate the patch safely if she used care.… As demonstrated by their answers on the special verdict form, the jury determined that the plaintiff fell on an ‘unnatural’ accumulation of snow or ice, that the dangerous nature of the accumulation was open and obvious….”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or person in control of premises has a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the property, including walkways and sidewalks under its control, in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors. See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707–08 (1973).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the landmark Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and imposing a general duty of reasonable care owed by property occupiers to all lawful entrants. The provided excerpt is from a concurrence and discusses classification issues (trespassers vs. licensees/invitees), not directly the duty to maintain walkways, but the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 707–08 clearly articulates that occupiers must exercise reasonable care to keep premises reasonably safe for lawful visitors. Thus, the case as a whole supports the stated proposition, even though the quoted passage does not itself address it.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.relevant_excerpt: “We therefore hold that the common law distinction between invitees and licensees shall no longer be recognized in this Commonwealth. The duty owed by an occupier of land to all lawful visitors is to act as a reasonable man in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.” (Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707–08 (1973).)

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: This duty of reasonable care includes taking reasonable steps to prevent or remedy the accumulation of snow and ice on walkways that are intended for use by tenants, guests, and invitees after a reasonable period of time following a storm, and after the owner undertakes snow removal. See Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 383–84 (2010).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: Papadopoulos abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation rule and holds that property owners owe lawful visitors a general duty of reasonable care with respect to snow and ice, but it does not articulate the more specific timing rule described in the proposition (i.e., a duty arising after a reasonable period of time following a storm and after the owner undertakes snow removal). The court explicitly defers any discussion of a ‘storm in progress’ or post-storm timing standard to a future case, and therefore does not establish that component of the claimed proposition.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … Under this traditional premises liability standard, a fact finder will determine what snow and ice removal efforts are reasonable in light of the expense they impose on the landowner and the probability and seriousness of the foreseeable harm to others.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant, as owner and/or person in control of the Premises and abutting sidewalk, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the sidewalk in a reasonably safe condition, including with respect to accumulations of snow and ice. See Papadopoulos, 457 Mass. at 383–84; G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence framework for tort actions).

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Defendant also owed Plaintiff a duty to take reasonable steps to guard against foreseeable risks of harm from dangerous conditions on the Premises of which Defendant knew or reasonably should have known. See Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739, 743 (1995).
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The court explicitly reaffirms the general premises-liability rule that a landowner owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care, which includes maintaining the premises in reasonably safe condition and warning of unreasonable dangers the owner knows or reasonably should know about. That language matches the cited proposition about a duty to guard against foreseeable risks of harm from dangerous conditions on the premises. Although the specific holding is that no duty extended to altering the adjacent state highway, the general duty rule on conditions of the premises is clearly stated and authoritative.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors… This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware. Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747 (1988). Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84, 88 (1988). Polak v. Whitney, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 349, 351 (1985).”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.proposition: Having created and held out this narrow shoveled path as the main means of pedestrian access, Defendant had a duty to perform snow and ice removal with reasonable care, including the use of salt, sand, or other treatment where reasonably necessary to prevent hazardous ice buildup. See Papadopoulos, 457 Mass. at 383–84; cf. Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154–55 (2013) (landowner liable where failure to maintain area of ingress/egress created foreseeable risk of harm).
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.support_reasoning: Dos Santos concerns a landowner’s duty to remedy an open and obvious danger that the landowner created and maintained (a trampoline set immediately adjacent to a shallow pool), and holds that a duty to remedy may exist despite obviousness. It does not involve snow or ice removal, nor does it discuss any obligation to use salt, sand, or similar treatment, or specifically address maintaining an area of ingress/egress. Citing Dos Santos for a duty to perform snow and ice removal with reasonable care, including salting or sanding, overstates and mischaracterizes its holding.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ Papadopoulos, supra, quoting Soederberg… On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of reasonable care required under Massachusetts law and therefore constitutes negligence. See Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696–97 (2000) (negligence based on failure to maintain premises in safe condition); Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 54–55 (1983) (duty defined by reasonable foreseeability of harm).
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.support_reasoning: Glidden v. Maglio does not hold that the defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of reasonable care or that it constitutes negligence. Instead, the SJC affirms summary judgment for the defendant because the plaintiffs failed to produce evidence of causation and did not show that any property defect chargeable to the defendant caused the scaffolding collapse. The case is therefore about the plaintiffs’ failure of proof (especially on causation and knowledge of a defect), not an articulation that the defendant’s conduct was negligent under Massachusetts law or based on a failure to maintain premises in a safe condition.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs…bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care… Causation is an essential element of that proof… The record reflects that the plaintiffs failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed and therefore cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty to them as either homeowner or general contractor, or because of any failure to warn of any purported defect on his property.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 54–55 (1983).
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of reasonable care required under Massachusetts law and therefore constitutes negligence. See Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696–97 (2000) (negligence based on failure to maintain premises in safe condition); Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 54–55 (1983) (duty defined by reasonable foreseeability of harm).
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The cited portion is from a dissent focusing on causation and foreseeability, not on whether defendants breached the duty of reasonable care. However, the dissent explicitly recites the governing Massachusetts negligence standard, including that a defendant is negligent if they take a risk a person of ordinary prudence would not and if the resulting injury is within the foreseeable risk. That aligns with the proposition’s use of Mullins for the foreseeability-based definition of duty; it does not, however, say that the specific defendant’s conduct in this case "fell below" the standard, only how the duty is defined.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969). The foreseeable risk of an inadequately secured gate is that an intruder might enter the premises for mischievous purposes.

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: Defendant’s negligent acts and omissions were a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s slip‑and‑fall on February 15, 2023, and of Plaintiff’s resulting injuries. See Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320 (2002) (causation where negligence is substantial contributing factor).
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The case does discuss proximate cause, but it does not stand for the general proposition that negligence is actionable whenever it is a substantial contributing factor. Instead, the court holds that, as a matter of law, the defendant’s earlier negligence was too remote and that intervening acts became a superseding cause, breaking proximate cause. Thus, Kent is actually authority limiting causation, not supporting liability based on a substantial contributing factor theory for a later injury such as a 2023 slip‑and‑fall.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. See Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1935). Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct. Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978). … [T]he INS action constituted a superseding cause of the harm that followed.”}

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871\u.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover for her past and future medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and any other compensable damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence. See G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence); see also Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871–72 (1991) (damages in negligence include pain and suffering and lost earnings).
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871\u.support_reasoning: The cited pages of Haddad v. Gonzalez concern recoverability of emotional distress damages and the measure of damages for breach of the warranty of habitability in a landlord-tenant/Chapter 93A context. The opinion does not discuss standard negligence damages, nor does it say that damages in negligence actions include pain and suffering and lost earnings. Thus, it is not proper authority for the broad negligence-damages proposition stated in the parenthetical.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871\u.relevant_excerpt: "In Leardi v. Brown, supra at 158-159, we held that, under the amended version of § 9 (1), the invasion of any legally protected right was compensable. In Maillet v. ATF-Davidson, Co., 407 Mass. 185 (1990), we clarified that this included invasions in the form of injury to the person. ... Because severe emotional distress is a form of personal injury, see Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 95, 111 (1982), it would seem to follow that it also is compensable under § 9, if the injury is the product of a violation of G.L. c. 93A, § 2."

Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc., 41.raw_text: Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590, 592–94 (1994).
Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc., 41.proposition: To the extent that the condition of the public sidewalk is implicated, Defendant, as abutting landowner who undertook control and maintenance of the sidewalk, is liable under common‑law negligence principles, consistent with Papadopoulos and cases addressing landowner duties to maintain areas of ingress and egress under their control. See Papadopoulos, 457 Mass. at 383–84; Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590, 592–94 (1994).
Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc., 41.support_reasoning: Barry is a premises‑liability case about a delivery driver slipping on ice on the defendant’s own delivery area. The opinion concerns the scope of a landowner’s duty and, specifically, whether the owner had actual or constructive notice of an icy condition on its property. It does not address public sidewalks, abutting landowners, or liability arising from an abutter’s undertaking to control or maintain a public way, so it does not support the sidewalk‑focused proposition for which it is cited.
Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc., 41.relevant_excerpt: “The law imposes on a property owner ‘a duty to maintain his property “in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.”’… Thus, a defendant who did not have a reasonable opportunity to discover and remedy a hazardous condition — that is, a defendant who had no actual or constructive knowledge of the allegedly hazardous condition so that it could not reasonably remove, or warn the plaintiff of, the danger — cannot be found to have violated its duty of care.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable as of right pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60, and applicable Massachusetts court rules.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 6C.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation from Defendant for all such damages in an amount to be determined by the trier of fact, plus interest and costs as allowed by law. See G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B, 6C.
